Met a government school dropout guy who spent his entire childhood in a chawl. His Parents made their lively hood being street side food vendor. He started his career as a junior clerk. In a span of 20 years today he runs a 300cr Top line company, giving direct employment to 160 people. His dream is to make it a 2000cr company over the next 3-4 years.  (Unlisted)

Every year he organizes a lucky draw in his company where he provides opportunity to staffs from bottom hierarchy to top, giving every one equal opportunity to win. 

I asked him why he has kept photos belonging to his initial days in cabin. He said life has shown him a lot of struggles and he doesn’t want to forget his origins. This helps him to stay grounded. 

Such is the story of many credible entrepreneurs who fought all odds, survived, thrived and now are giving back to the society through different means. 

Honored and Humbled to meet such entrepreneurs. Tier 2-3 cities have many such aspiring stories waiting to be heard. India will see many such entrepreneurs rising to glory from ashes, Bet on them Bet On 🇮🇳⚙️

full_text:
If your conviction on promoter is strong, then be rest assured whatever the promoter does comes with lot of back hand calculation, backup plans and risk mitigation measures. That doesn’t protect him from all external shocks, but in majority cases a strong promoter knows how to navigate his ship through the storm.

Just like the leader MS Dhoni giving 2007 world cup final last over to Joginder Sharma (thought being he did not want to provide pace to Misbah) or making Sehwag, Harbajan and Robin Utthapa to bowl the famous super over against Pakistan.

Neither of the above were fluke decisions, they were well thought out strategies.

How Lets see?

Observe in the image, Dhoni kneels behind the stumps and positions himself in such a manner that his shoulder frame exactly fits behind the stump frame. So the bowler has to just see Dhoni and bowl at him. MSD just helped the bowler to widen his horizon.  This improved the accuracy level of the bowler and gives him the extra confidence when he bowls.

Compared to Pakistan wicket keeper who stood far behind stumps and their bowlers bowled slow medium pace thereby losing balance and sight of the target.

The role of a great leader is not to give greatness to human beings but to help them extract the greatness they already have inside them.

full_text:
Who faces the disruption risk? Existing Players or New Players.. Lets see

Whenever a new trend gets started multiple entrants get attracted, but only few make it to the end when there is consolidation later. This doesn’t mean the newbies don’t have a chance to thrive and evolve. This is an incorrect perception to possess, which can lead to wrong fallacy. As in case of EV, recently Tesla and Foxcon have started proceedings to enter the EV market in India. This will only expand the market and encourage more people towards mass adaptation of EV.

 Recently MG launched Comet EV, and created a new market for EV micro cars which didn’t exist earlier. Going forward more companies will enter this space, and there will be market available for everyone to capture with costs coming down. (Read how micro cars became a success in China) Contrary to the opinion where many feels the market gets shrinked when a big player enters a sunrise space, its actually happens the reverse way where the market expands and the adaptation increases. All boils down to the value for money and differentiating factors that the brand offers. It's not the size of the dog in the fight, it's the size of the fight in the dog. We have seen many market leaders perish to extinction as they were unable to evolve with time (Nokia, Kodak, General Motors).So if at all anyone faces the risk of extinction more its the one that is unwilling to adapt. The new incumbents are the ones wihtout any baggage and they have nothing to lose. They are the ones that generally disrupt and the existing leaders are the ones that get disrupted as they have everything to lose.

We are at the cusp of biggest automobile revolution since beginning and the least we must do is dismiss it saying EV don't have a chance. Of course there will be stiff competition but winners will also emerge. 

Ancillaries are a good way to play the EV Megatrend. But In case of ancillaries, the threat of disruption is more prone towards those catering to engine and components in ICE space as we move towards EV. Engines and transmission components , Clutch, Radiators are facing high disruption risk compared to those with supplying suspension, breaks, lighting etc. When disruption happens in a stagnant market its the legacy players that lose market share fast. 

The 3 hurdles for EV adoption are  Range Anxiety, High Upfront Cost(Battery Cost) and Resale Value. As and when we shift towards mass adoption of EVs these problems would gradually dissolve through continues R&D process.

When initially 'Hyundai Santro' was launched it was labelled as a tall boy car, gradually people accepted it and Maruti launched 'Wagon R' on similar lines which became a massive hit. There are few products that are launched ahead of their time, but once they click there is no looking back. Remember Dil Chahta Hai movie, which was way ahead of its time when released in 2001 and Andaz Apna Apna in 1994, post their release they achieved a cult status. In my opinion EV will see a similar fate.

We can also take example of SME investing. Many big funds have started to notice SME cos in micro caps space, this is a positive sign for the whole ecosystem. Their entry will only be beneficial to the existing SME shareholders. 

The summary is new players entering into a lucrative space will expand the market and benefit the consumers. It is about Survival Of The Fittest. The fittest are those endowed with the qualifications for adaptation, the ability to accept the inevitable and conform to the unavoidable, to harmonize with existing or changing conditions.

So the answer to our question who faces the disruption risk most would be the one that is unwilling to adapt. 

 “It is not the strongest of the species that survives, nor the most intelligent; it is the one most adaptable to change.” — Charles Darwin.

Two critical challenges for the Msme sector was lack of Financial Assistance and Management Bandwidth. Post listing management bandwidth gets sorted out mostly as the companies that were partnership entities evolve their structure to limited company and hire professionals. 

The financial assistance is now being addressed by TReDS. 

The Trade Receivables Discounting System or TReDS (Trade Receivables Discounting System) is an online platform that allows MSME suppliers to discount their bills and invoices. The RBI launched the Trade Receivables Discounting System in 2018. The platform enables MSMEs to receive payments more quickly. The TReDS’ main purpose is to allow MSME sellers to discount invoices raised against major corporations, which helps them manage their working capital demands.

This is a very essential change in eco system that will help MSME’s to address their working capital crunch. Going forward this platform should continue to serve many MSMe's and help them in their growth journey..

Ecosystem for MSME today and few years back is completely different. Today they are playing on a better wicket as two critical issues are being addressed well. Investors often label a promoter as good/bad based upon the deliverance of financials which can depend upon many factors like macros, govt policies, supply demand dynamics etc. 

One has to understand a business goes through many ups and downs cycles over a period of time and a promoter is often a bystander here as beyond a point he cannot control the outcomes for his business. 

Definition of a bad Promoter in market terms is generally linked to stock price performance. If stock does well the promoter is the hero and if doesn't he is the villain. One needs to understand why they went wrong by listening to them. During a muted earnings phase good companies focus more on strengthening their Research and Development or spent more on process innovation which helps them during good times.

 These things won't reflect in the market cap rise often in the near term but work wonders over a longer period. Hence as an investor one needs to exercise some caution before labelling a promoter as bad just because the stock price didn't perform as per their lofty expectations.

 A Promoter exploiting minority shareholders and siphoning funds from company is not same as promoter going though a rough patch in business lifecycle. One has to understand the circumstances and intentions behind and not judge simply on the basis of price movement.

Everyone knows Manufacturing was on tailspin last decade. You pick any companies in this space all would have underperformed. Even the best moated companies need a catalyst to perform well. In last 1 year we invested in four companies where the promoters were labelled as not so good based on last decade performance. 

We were lucky enough to not skip them just by hearing to consensus views. We decided to understand the challenges that these businesses faced over the last decade and did our own ground work which worked out phenomenally well for us. 

You cannot get all answers in Social Media. Most investors are high on Talent side but get check mate on Behaviour side. 

"Don't be an Investor who lives in the present, wants to invest for the future but gets discouraged seeing the past track record which was based upon past circumstances"

They crack the success code outside their comfort zone. A commerce graduate runs a successful API/Agrochemical company. A person from finance background runs a top notch pharma company. What they do right is, hire highly competent professionals and give them a  free hand to drive the company operations by  developing their own unique methodology.

Wipro owned by Azim Prem Ji owns several businesses. Even though Prem Ji himself never wrote any code, He built different sets of businesses. Statistics are mere numbers devoid of any emotions. Unless you can analyze and interpret, they have little to offer. Investing is surely beyond numbers. It's our ability to visualize where  company’s trajectory is shaping a few years down the line which will determine the outcome. By using Data, which is available and accessible to everyone, we can create a strategy, but these are all mechanical touches. The X factor comes from Human Touches which are impossible to measure & predict.  (How do you quantify & measure - Patience,  Mindset, Vision, Courage, Emotions, Perseverance, Dedication, Temperament & Wisdom).

 Let's dive into the past. 

Robert Mc Namara was hired by Henry Ford II to help turn around Ford Motors, during World War II, which he did successfully. Later he was asked to lead the Department of Defense at the Pentagon,  during the Vietnam War, where he used the same logic as he used at Ford. He was a hard-core statistical guy and demanded everything to be quantified with daily, weekly & monthly charts. This strategy had a major flaw when used at the Pentagon. It ignored the feelings of Vietnamese people. There was a central issue with managing the  Vietnam War. Americans were killing Vietnamese at a ratio of 10:1. The American people didn’t care about the life of 10 Vietnamese but they certainly cared about that 1 American life. 

Ho Chi Minh, Former President of North Vietnam, bluntly stated “You will kill ten of us, and we will kill one of you, but it is you who will tire first”.  It's hard to contextualize that on a chart.

We are a young country, aspiring to become a large & impactful community.  What we ignored was the human aspects of the first-generation promoters and relied too much on data & statistics, hence lot of us missed the unprecedented boom in the market. When we have nothing to lose and have all the zest to take on the challenges/ hurdles, then we increase the probability to emerge as a winner. Life shrinks or expands in proportion to one’s courage.

full_text:
To counter the Chinese intervention in Surveillance Cameras, The government has amended the compulsory registration order for CCTV cameras sold in India to make testing of their 'essential security parameters' mandatory.

Securing a CCTV (Closed-Circuit Television) system is crucial to protect sensitive information and ensure the system operates effectively. Key areas of testing include exposed network services, device communication protocols, physical access to the device’s UART, JTAG, SWD, etc., the ability to extract memory and firmware, firmware update process security and storage and encryption of data.

The Union Government has come out with safety guidelines keeping national security as top priority.

Till date, the Indian Government had no mechanism to check the installation of these Chinese-origin surveillance cameras, as the certification for such devices in use in the country only looked into aspects such as fire hazard or durability, and not security or snooping threats.

China’s Hikvision controlled India’s surveillance market. US had already invoked the National Defense Authorization Act and prohibited government agencies from purchasing video surveillance products from Hikvision.

Hikvision is one of the world’s largest video surveillance companies producing both hardware and software tools.Hikvision exists in India under the name Prama Hikvision Indian Private Limited. As per reports, Hikvision enjoys over 35 per cent market share in India

It is also listed as a vendor by Bharat Electronics (BEL), which works on highly sensitive and classified defence projects for the government of India. More worryingly, Hikvision has allegedly also supplied solutions to Delhi Metro Rail Corporation (DMRC), Defence Research and Development Organisation (DRDO), and the Special Protection Group (SPG), which is responsible for the security of the prime minister.

This leaves India with a tricky situation. Admittedly such companies do create secondary economic benefits for India with the local assembly and selling units creating jobs at home. However, there is arguably a bigger price India  pays in terms of handing its CCTV grid to a country that  is a threat to our national security.

However recently the Govt felt it's high time We need to reclaim our physical territory along with our digital spaces. 

So Govt of India banned 17 Chinese companies from participating in tenders in India and also warned private companies that do business with Govt entities against using these Chinese products.

Banned companies include Highvision,
 Hikvision, Lenovo, Dahua, Lava, Xolo, Airpro, Nokia etc.

This will not only prevent Chinese companies from snooping into Indian National security but also give a massive thrust to domestic manufacturers to reclaim the market share that used to be dominated by the Chinese.

Above was just an example, this pattern is being repeated across many sectors where capability to produce in India is already present and Sovereignty of INDIA is under threat. We have the right to govern ourselves without any external interference.

Mandatory BIS certification is the most under discussed and under rated trigger that has the consequences to make or break any company.

 BIS certification refers to the process of obtaining a quality standard certificate from the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) for manufacturing and selling various products in India. Sale of BIS Mandatory Products within the country requires adherence to applicable Indian standards and the inclusion of the standard mark. Failure to meet these criteria results in the prohibition of selling such products within India. So basically, the Government is expanding the items under BIS making the registration compulsory there by indirectly stopping the imports from other countries. As per the QCO, after a particular date no large-scale/small scale manufacturer along with foreign manufacturer can sell in India without license, and also they won’t get custom clearance. 

Recently BIS registration was introduced for domestic stainless steel vacuum flask bottle, Insulated Container for Food Storage, which was published on 13th June, 2024 in the official gazette.

Similarly, following products also have been introduced to have BIS certification:-

-BIS ISI Mark  for Kitchen Electrical Appliances 
-BIS-ISI Mark Certification for Polypropelene Materials for Moulding and Extrusion
-BIS Certification for Cast Iron Products
-BIS Certification for Fire Extinguishers
-BIS Certification for Poly Vinyl Chloride (PVC) Homopolymers
-BIS Certification for Morpholine
-BIS Certification for Water Meters and Accessories
And many others...

As an Investor we have to remain updated with the various guidelines being introduced by the central govt to boost local manufacturing. The domestic market is being opened up in massive way for all MSMEs who have manufacturing facilities along with testing facilities. This low hanging fruit can change the scenario for many domestic companies enabling them to take market share from their foreign counterparts.

full_text:
*"Accept. Adapt. Act. The past is gone, but the next big opportunity is still ahead!"*

During a market correction, one of the biggest psychological challenges investors face is accepting the decline in their portfolio’s value. The mind struggles to adjust to the new level, leading to regret over not selling at the peak and a constant cycle of lamentation. This emotional turmoil often brings to mind the song "Ae waqt ruk ja, tham ja, thehar ja, wapas jara, laut piche..."—a reflection of the desire to turn back time.

However, instead of dwelling on past losses, investors should take the following steps:

• Accept the new reality – The most important step is to wholeheartedly accept the current portfolio value as determined by the market. Acceptance reduces stress and allows for clearer decision-making.

• Assess and optimize the portfolio – Use this period to introspect and evaluate your holdings. Identify strong performers and allocate more capital to the best ideas, while reconsidering investments in underperforming companies/management. 

• Learn from past mistakes – Reflect on the errors made in the previous bull market to avoid repeating them in the future.

• Develop a positive mindset and stay proactive – A market correction presents new opportunities. Many potential multi-baggers are still available. The key is to identify and invest in them with a fresh perspective.

• Focus on the bigger picture – In times of distress, we often overlook the positive developments happening in our country. There are numerous exciting investment themes and "Make in India" opportunities unfolding. History has shown that we have always come back stronger, and this time will be no different.

There may be people who can claim they are correct for short term (Maine Bola Tha). But when you are investing for long term there is hardly any incentive to sell and reenter again. Even if you give me a second chance and say market will fall sell everything, my decision would still be to hold all  stocks where I have conviction and not time it by selling to buyback lower.

 For being right in long term you have to appear wrong in short term.

Happy Investing

In investing, mindset is more important than knowledge 📖

You can have all the fundamental knowledge on Investing, expertise on the sectors, market data, the best strategies, and deep financial expertise, but without the right mindset—discipline, patience, emotional control, and resilience—you’ll still struggle to succeed. 

The market doesn’t reward intelligence alone; it rewards those who can manage risk, stay calm during volatility, and make rational decisions under pressure. Many investors  fail not because they lack knowledge but because they can’t control their emotions. They panic when the market drops, chase hype, or let fear stop them from holding onto good investments.

Two people can have the same information, yet one profits while the other loses simply due to their psychological approach. A strong mindset allows you to stay focused on long-term goals, resist impulsive decisions, and navigate uncertainty with confidence. 

Investing is 80% psychology and 20% knowledge on investing. 

Strong minds suffer without complaining , Weak minds complain without suffering. Success isn't given, it's earned through hard work, a strong mindset and refusing to give up.

Stay patient when others panic, Be disciplined when greed takes over, Be resilient and persistent when setbacks occur—you’ll naturally make better financial decisions. 

Success in the markets isn’t about knowing everything; it’s about having the mental toughness to apply what you know effectively. *Mindset turns knowledge into wealth*
